trans-unit.source: How To Configure TLS Mutual Authentication for Web App
trans-unit.target: How To Configure TLS Mutual Authentication for Web App

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: You can restrict access to your Azure web app by enabling different types of authentication for it.
trans-unit.target: You can restrict access to your Azure web app by enabling different types of authentication for it.

trans-unit.source: One way to do so is to authenticate using a client certificate when the request is over TLS/SSL.
trans-unit.target: One way to do so is to authenticate using a client certificate when the request is over TLS/SSL.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism is called TLS mutual authentication or client certificate authentication and this article will detail how to setup your web app to use client certificate authentication.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism is called TLS mutual authentication or client certificate authentication and this article will detail how to setup your web app to use client certificate authentication.

trans-unit.source: Configure Web App for Client Certificate Authentication
trans-unit.target: Configure Web App for Client Certificate Authentication

trans-unit.source: To setup your web app to require client certificates you need to add the clientCertEnabled site setting for your web app and set it to true.
trans-unit.target: To setup your web app to require client certificates you need to add the clientCertEnabled site setting for your web app and set it to true.

trans-unit.source: This setting is not currently available through the management experience in the portal, and the REST API will need to be used to accomplish this.

trans-unit.source: Accessing the Client Certificate From Your Web App
trans-unit.target: Accessing the Client Certificate From Your Web App

trans-unit.source: When your web app is configured to use client certificate authentication, the client cert will be available in your app through a base64 encoded value in the "X-ARR-ClientCert" request header.
trans-unit.target: When your web app is configured to use client certificate authentication, the client cert will be available in your app through a base64 encoded value in the "X-ARR-ClientCert" request header.

trans-unit.source: Your application can create a certificate from this value and then use it for authentication and authorization purposes in your application.
trans-unit.target: Your application can create a certificate from this value and then use it for authentication and authorization purposes in your application.

trans-unit.source: Special Considerations for Certificate Validation
trans-unit.target: Special Considerations for Certificate Validation

trans-unit.source: The client certificate that is sent to the application does not go through any validation by the Azure Web Apps platform.
trans-unit.target: The client certificate that is sent to the application does not go through any validation by the Azure Web Apps platform.

trans-unit.source: Validating this certificate is the responsibility of the web app.
trans-unit.target: Validating this certificate is the responsibility of the web app.
